title: Holly Hill Woodland Park Walking Route

images.title: Hugh Venables / Holly Hill Woodland Park
images.caption: Holly Hill Woodland Park.  A generally well kept Victorian garden, managed by Fareham Borough Council. Like many areas planted by Victorians (and others) there are areas of Rhododendrons that, if left uncontrolled, will spread through the woodland. Some signs of management work on it.

images.title: Freda  Green / The  Lake,   Holly  Hill
images.caption: The Lake. Light on the water at Holly Hill park near Locksheath

images.title: Richard Dorrell / Path in the woodland park
images.caption: Path in the woodland park. Holly Hill woodland park belongs to Fareham Borough Council, and is 35 hectares of historic parkland stretching down to the River Hamble. Here, a walkway has been built over an often muddy stretch of footpath.

images.title: Colin Babb / Pond in Holly Hill Woodland Park
images.caption: One of several in this woodland park

images.title: Richard Dorrell / Holly Hill woodland park
images.caption: The park consists of some unique landscape features having developed since the 1870s with the planting of specimen trees around the lake area, some of which are still present in the park today. The lake is on the right in this picture.

images.title: Colin Babb / Tree Stump in Holly Hill Woodland Park
images.caption: Carved Tree Stump in the park

description: This short circular walk takes you through the peaceful Holly Hill Woodland Park and along the estuary of the River Hamble. The park has two distinctive areas - Winnards Copse with a more formal landscape, lakes and ornamental exotic species and Cawtes Copse with its mix of native woodland species. There are two way marked trails of varying length following the footpath network around the site. The park is located in Sarisbury near Southampton and Fareham .
